channel.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
channel.description:
lel its still private and in making but it works so far, here is a pic more info tmrow its 2 late now lel how hax it is: all the tiles can be modified, i made a map editor to edit maps, i can add my own tiles, my own sprites, /win tiles can teleport, be wild pokemon encounters, and be just plain walls [img]http://img261.imageshack.us/img261/6103/tbhat2.png[/img] dis pic wuz by chez pulic thx 4 test lel
Plans Ahead: [s]chat[/s] [s]pokemans!!![/s] wild batals [s]giv myself wal hak[/s]

item.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
item.dc:creator: @Carson Carson
item.description:
@Carson wrote:

Walk up to the player.

Hit ‘a’

Brings up a menu.

‘t’ for talk.
‘b’ for battle.
‘p’ to view pokemon
‘e’ to exit.

83% Credits to Telenubby, 17% to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Haha. That’s always a way.
But how about a legal way?

Regarding your player-options:
Walk up to Player A.
Click the button O (for options) or T (for talk).
Opens up player-options interface.
You and Player A can successfully bang.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Message(#6851-000668-1828\6681828)

Hello,

We appreciate the interest in Nintendo and in all our video game products. To us, it represents a great sign of success and recognition of the Nintendo brand.

“Nintendo” is a registered trademark of Nintendo of America Inc. Nintendo owns extensive intellectual property rights in all of its products, including video game systems, game titles, characters, game software, graphics, artwork, and screen shots. Nintendo also retains rights in content on Nintendo’s websites, including articles, artwork, screen shots and other files. Trademarks and copyrights for third-party games and characters are owned by the companies which market or license those products.

While we are grateful for all the requests for permission to use Nintendo properties, we are not able to grant such requests. We receive thousands of requests and do not have adequate staffing to review them all. Therefore, our general policy is to decline requests for permission for the use of Nintendo properties.

Although we are unable to grant permission, use of Nintendo’s properties without formal permission by Nintendo may still be allowed under the relevant laws of the particular jurisdiction involved. Thus, we encourage you to seek your own legal counsel if you have any questions about whether your particular proposed use is permitted without Nintendo’s authorization. Nintendo cannot provide legal advice.

We appreciate your support. For more information about Nintendo and its products, please visit our website at www.nintendo.com.

Nintendo of America Inc.
R.M. Rickets

Nintendo’s home page: http://www.nintendo.com/
Power Line (Automated Product Info): (425) 885-7529

Take our Survey! You have been chosen to participate in an e-mail quality survey. This should take less than 5 minutes. Please click here: http://www.nintendo.com/consumersurvey.jsp?ref=telenubby@yahoo.com

ORIGINAL MESSAGE:

From: telenubby@yahoo.com
Posted At: 17:26:01.000 03/17/2008
Posted To: Nintendo nintendo@noa.nintendo.com
Subject: Webform: Other Non-Product Related > Other

Hello, Nintendo Staff.
I come to you for answers to my questions.
Lately, I’ve had the idea of developing a program in Java. It would have two parts. A client, and of course, a server. This whole idea would be wrapped around the Pokemon theme - but with a twist. I would allow an online-play feature, nothing else. No single-player, no campaign, nothing. Just simple online-play all around the world. I’ve talked to some friends, and they say that this would be copyright infringement. I’ve looked into it, but could not find an assuring answer. So now I come to you for advice. This online game would be something similar to the older Red/Blue/Yellow versions of the game. The sprites and other images used in-game would be very similar or exact to the ones you have created. I could map out the original Pokemon map that you have created, or create one of my own, just for this fun online experience.
Would making a program that meets the above description be against the law? Would you care? Are there any adjustments to its current idea that you would approve of? In-game ‘membership’ deals - what do you think of those? How about ads on the website creating income for me, but not directly related to the game (e.g. Google AdSense)?
If you could please answer those questions, I’d be grateful. I’ve already started on this project and I’m not sure wether to continue or not. I don’t want this to be a total waste of time, but it’d be a learning experience for sure.
Many thanks,
TeleNubby.


Doubt you care, but I took the time earlier to contact them.

Anyways, in their second to last paragraph, how would it be possible to make Multiplayer Pokemon legal, or able-to-use without Nintendo’s permission?

Read full topic

item.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Glad to see you are still working on this, I thought about it a few weeks ago and thought “Ah he probably gave up, was a great idea though”.
Keep up with it though.

I think as suggested above, go up to someone and press a button to send a request, sort of like, dare i say it, like how it was in Runescape Classic where you could “Duel” anywhere.

Don’t be put off because I said the Runescape word, and you probably already thought of this, but i think its probably the best idea.

Read full topic

item.title: Multiplayer Pokemon
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I think the lobby is still best imo. Just make a building where the players ‘sign up’ to battle another player, and the server stores them in a list and prioritize them depending on how long they have been waiting. It then pairs them up with another player and they are teleported to an arena where their pokemon can sex each other.

AIDS is a ‘descendant’ of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV). The most widely accepted means by which it was passed on to humans is that an infected primate was hunted and consumed - the virus then mutated (as HIV is infamous for), becoming HIV.
